author: JuliaRegistrator

comments.body:
Your `new package` pull request does not meet the guidelines for auto-merging. Please make sure that you have read the [General registry README](https://github.com/JuliaRegistries/General/blob/master/README.md) and the [AutoMerge guidelines](https://juliaregistries.github.io/RegistryCI.jl/stable/guidelines/). The following guidelines were not met:

- There is no compat entry for `julia`.

Note that the guidelines are only required for the pull request to be merged automatically. However, it is **strongly recommended** to follow them, since otherwise the pull request needs to be manually reviewed and merged by a human.

After you have fixed the AutoMerge issues, simple retrigger Registrator, which will automatically update this pull request. You do not need to change the version number in your `Project.toml` file (unless of course the AutoMerge issue is that you skipped a version number, in which case you should change the version number).

If you do not want to fix the AutoMerge issues, please post a comment explaining why you would like this pull request to be manually merged. Then, send a message to the `#pkg-registration` channel in the [Julia Slack](https://julialang.org/slack/) to ask for help. Include a link to this pull request.

Since you are registering a new package, please make sure that you have also read the package naming guidelines: https://julialang.github.io/Pkg.jl/dev/creating-packages/#Package-naming-guidelines-1



---
If you want to prevent this pull request from being auto-merged, simply leave a comment. If you want to post a comment without blocking auto-merging, you must include the text `[noblock]` in your comment. You can edit blocking comments, adding `[noblock]` to them in order to unblock auto-merging.
<!-- [noblock] -->
<!---
this_is_the_single_automerge_comment
--->
Shouldn’t this be called `FeynmanAmplitudeTools`? There are many many “amplitudes”, so I would consider this name to be too general

> Shouldn’t this be called `FeynmanAmplitudeTools`? There are many many “amplitudes”, so I would consider this name to be too general

We have discussed about the naming again. If you still think AmplitudeTools, we have another name as FeAmBase. Could it be okay?

No `FeAmBase` is a terrible name. See https://pkgdocs.julialang.org/dev/creating-packages/#Package-naming-guidelines-1, point 4. Don’t be afraid of a long package name! It’s more or less what is expected in the Julia community.

> No `FeAmBase` is a terrible name. See https://pkgdocs.julialang.org/dev/creating-packages/#Package-naming-guidelines-1, point 4. Don’t be afraid of a long package name! It’s more or less what is expected in the Julia community.

We have seen this point of the guidelines. However, it is not the naming convention in the HEP community for the computation tools. For example, the name like FeynmanAmplitudeBase or FeynmanAmplitudeTools would be too difficult to be accepted by the HEP community. We still prefer the name `FeAmBase` or `FeAmTools`.

That doesn't make sense to me. To the extent that the HEP community is using Julia, they (you) should be adapting to Julia naming conventions. There is no HEP-Julia sub-community that somehow has different rules. I think what you're trying to say is that the HEP community has so far been using *other languages*, which have their own conventions. But those conventions are incompatible with Julia's conventions, and you should leave them at the door. 

That being said, the naming is ultimately your prerogative. So yeah, if you insist, you can register it with `FeAmBase` and it will either be merged automatically or a maintainer will (begrudgingly) merge it manually.

How about `FeynmanAmp(Tools|Base)`?

It is important to reinforce that the General Registry is a common package marketplace and its contents should be of usage by the Julia public in general. This requires packages like this to be characterized by their context.

If you are sticking to the proposed names, there is still life outside the General Registry:
- Including in your README that it should be installed directly via git, i.e., `Pkg.add(url="https://github.com/zhaoli-IHEP/AmplitudeTools.jl")`
- Creating a local registry for HEP: [LocalRegistry.jl](https://github.com/GunnarFarneback/LocalRegistry.jl)

I would also recommend changing the name of the yet unregistered https://github.com/zhaoli-IHEP/FeAmGen.jl

@ExpandingMan suggested `FeynmanSymTools` on Slack to highlight the connection to `SymEngine`. Maybe consider this as another alternative for either this package or `FeAmGen`

You just *might* be able to get away with shortening `Feynman` to `Feyn`, so `FeynAmpBase`, `FeynSymTools` (which are actually shorter than the original `AmplitudeTools`), although I would still urge you to go with the longer `Feynman…` names for more clarity

> 



> How about `FeynmanAmp(Tools|Base)`?
> 
> It is important to reinforce that the General Registry is a common package marketplace and its contents should be of usage by the Julia public in general. This requires packages like this to be characterized by their context.
> 
> If you are sticking to the proposed names, there is still life outside the General Registry:
> 
> * Including in your README that it should be installed directly via git, i.e., `Pkg.add(url="https://github.com/zhaoli-IHEP/AmplitudeTools.jl")`
> * Creating a local registry for HEP: [LocalRegistry.jl](https://github.com/GunnarFarneback/LocalRegistry.jl)

Thank you for the helpful information. We could choose this approach.

> You just _might_ be able to get away with shortening `Feynman` to `Feyn`, so `FeynAmpBase`, `FeynSymTools` (which are actually shorter than the original `AmplitudeTools`), although I would still urge you to go with the longer `Feynman…` names for more clarity

Dear Goerz, 
Thank you so much for your kind help. After serious consideration, since our naming convention may have conflict with the Julia naming guidelines, we will give up registering into the Julia General Registry to avoid the contamination.

This pull request has been inactive for 30 days and will be automatically closed 7 days from now. If this pull request should not be closed, please either (1) fix the AutoMerge issues and re-trigger Registrator, which will automatically update the pull request, or (2) post a comment explaining why you would like this pull request to be manually merged. [noblock]
This pull request has been inactive for more than 30 days and has automatically been closed. Feel free to register your package or version again once you fix the AutoMerge issues. [noblock]
